questions.text: The marked structure is supplied by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median Nerve

Highyeild:

Thenar Space: Index finger tendon & 1 st Lumbrical Mid palmar space: Middle finger, Ring & Little fingers 2nd 3rd & 4th Lumbricals Forearm Space of Parona: The place where Radial & Ulnar bursa joins Infection of Little finger can go to thumb but not to index finger 1st two lumbricals supplied by Median nerve, 3rd & 4 th Lumbricals are supplied by Ulnar nerve ALSO NOTE: Thenar space: A bursa (potential space) just palmar to adductor pollicis and dorsal to flexor tendons Separated from midpalmar potential space by a fascial septum Midpalmar space Located dorsal and radial to hypothenar space Hypothenar space Located palmar to fifth metacarpal, dorsal and radial to hypothenar fascia, ulnar to hypothenar septum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - AIN Option B - PIN Option D - Ulnar Nerve

Table:

#Mantra Carpal tunnel→ median nerve Guyon's canal → Ulnar nerve Pronator syndrome → Median n. under pronator teres Chieralgia paresthetica branch of Radial n. superficial Cubital tunnel syndrome → ulnar n. between 2 heads of FCU Radial tunnel syndrome → Origin of ECRB Radial head Arcade of Frohse Radial Recurrent Arterial Fan Thoracic outlet syndrome → Lower trunk of brachial plexus Inguinal ligament Lat. Cut. N. of thigh→ Meralgia paresthetica Fibular neck → common peroneal n. → Foot drop Tarsal tunnel Tibial n. Digits (toes) metatarsalgia Digital n. → Morton's

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paradiscal Tuberculosis of Bone and joints: Order of involvement : Spine>Hip>Knee TB spine is known as Potts ‘spine.

Highyeild:

Characteristics Of Pott’s Spine: Two vertebral disease Involves both vertebra and disc Winking Owl Sign: Destruction of one of the pedicles Blind bat sign: Destruction of both the pedicles Earliest symptom and sign: Pain and tenderness

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Paradiscal Option B - central - Option C - Anterior disease Type of involvement Imaging findings 1 Paradiscal (most common) Involves adjacent margins of two consecutive vertebrae with reduced intervening disc space 2 Central Involves central portion of a vertebra; proximal and distal disc spaces are intact 3 Anterior Begins as destructive lesion in one of the anterior margins of the vertebral body, minimally involving the disc spaces 4 Posterior elements Involves posterior arch usually without involvement of body Option D - Posterior elements and single vertebral disease if involved, patient has malignancy

Table:

#Mantra Winking Owl Sign: Destruction of one of the pedicles Blind bat sign: Destruction of both the pedicles Earliest symptom and sign: Pain and tenderness
